    Free EPG data with WebGrab+Plus and TVHeadend

    16 minute read

    Carlos Gomes

    I’m a scientist, psychologist, math modeler, programmer, mtg player, free knowledge supporter, sbc fanatic, and electronics hobbyist.

    • Brazil
    • Main e-mail
    • https://cgomesu.com

    Introduction

    This is a guide for anyone interested in learning how to grab EPG data from publicly available sources (online TV guides) and feed them to an IPTV server. We will accomplish the former with a free program called WebGrab+Plus (WG++) and the latter, with a free and open-source program called TVHeadend (TVH).

    Initially, I wrote this guide as a complementary piece to my previous one on how to play Youtube live-streams as if they were IPTV channels. For this reason, I won’t go into too much detail about how to install and configure a TVH server. If you don’t have a TVH server up and running, I recommend you to take a look at my previous guide and the official documentation. However, if all you want is to learn about EPG data and WG++, then read on and skip the content about interacting with a TVH server or use the Table of Contents to skip directly to the content about WG++ configuration and automation.

    I might make changes to this article after posting it. If I do, there will be an “update tracker” at the beggining of the article stating what was changed and when.

    Motivation

    Objectives

    Server-Client Layout

    top

    WebGrab+Plus

    WG++ is a free (but unfortunately, not open source) application that grabs and parses EPG data from multiple public websites that contain TV guides (e.g., https://www.tvguide.co.uk/). That is, instead of paying an EPG data provider, you can use this program to collect EPG data from freely available online sources. Recently, however, the WG++ devs have started implementing user-licenses to mitigate abuse and provide benefits to users who donate. Last time I checked (May 20th), user-licenses have been disabled by the devs after an initial trial period. However, if you do run into license issues, check their Forums to find out how to obtain one (a ‘registered user’ license is free and you can obtain one by simply registering an account, as the name implies). Don’t abuse their application. If you like it, please donate.

    Installation and notes

    To install WG++, first download the latest version for your OS. Then, go to the official guide and follow the instructions to install on a Linux machine (or Windows).

    If you’re running Linux, you’ll need to install mono in order to run the WG++ executable. When doing so, I suggest you to install all three mono-devel mono-complete ca-certificates-mono to avoid running onto issues with missing mono packages. Please note that this will take some time (be patient).

    Also, for the remaining part of this guide, I’ll assume you’re running Linux but you should be able to figure out the Windows equivalent of the terminal commands if you’ve used both OSes before.

    After extracting the WG++ file downloaded from the download website, WG++ will create a .wg++/ folder on whatever folder you chose as destination. For the sake of simplicity, I suggest you to move it to the /home/ folder of your main user account (e.g., /home/cgomesu/.wg++/) if you’ve extracted the compressed file to a different location. In any case, take note of where the .wg++/ folder is because we will refer to it multiple times.

    Per their guide, once you’ve downloaded and extracted the compressed file, run the install shell script to create the template configuration files :

    cd ~/.wg++
bash install.sh

    Then, test the program by running the run shell scrit, as follows:

    bash run.sh

    This will execute the run.sh script using the default WebGrab++.config.xml configuration file that has a single dummy channel. If it’s working correctly, the run.sh script will output something that looks like this:

    If your output doesn’t look like that one or has noticeable errors, then try to make sense of the error message and review your installation. There’s no point to continue if your application is broken. Reinstall the whole thing and give it another try. Because WG++ is a Windows executable, problems running it on Linux machines are often related to missing or outdated mono packages (mono --version will tell you the mono version you’ve installed, which should be 6.8+ at this point), so make sure to review those, too.

    If everything looks good, then you’re ready to configure your WG++ application. Basic config first, then advanced shit.

    Basic configuration

    You can find detailed instructions on how to configure your WG++ on the official website. Here, however, I’ll cover only those that are necessary to get you started with the program.

    All the main settings are specified in the WebGrab++.config.xml file on the .wg++/ folder. Open it with your favorite text editor (e.g., nano, pluma) and you should see something like this:

    The way this file is organized should be fairly intuitive. All the configuration options should be within <settings></settings> and the only thing you’ll need to edit are the following:

    <!-- comment -->

    Text within <!-- --> are comments used for quick reference in a XML file. You’ll notice that some options are part of the default file but are commented out (see license, for example). To enable such options, you can simply remove the comment markers (<!-- -->).

    <license>

    As I mentioned before, the WG++ devs have started using licenses recently. If you’re only going to grab data from less than 20 channels from one or two sources, don’t even bother with this. However, if you need data for more channels, you should look into how to acquire a license. (Again, licenses were deactivated when I first wrote this guide, so you shouldn’t need one at all.) If you have a license, uncomment the <license></license> row and edit it with your credentials (notice that the password is your license password, not your account password). For example:

    <license wg-username="example" registered-email="example@example.com" password="password123" />

    <timespan>

    This indicates the timespan (in days since today) of the EPG data WG++ will attempt to grab. The default is 0, meaning only grab EPG data from today. I usually set this value to 2, which is today and the next 2 days, as follows:

    <timespan>2</timespan>

    <update>

    There are five update modes: channel, incremental, light, smart, and force/full. The default is force (f), which downloads all the data and overwrites whatever you’ve grabbed in the past whenever you run WG++. If left blank, then it will used the update="" directive in the channel element (this is useful if you want more fine-grained settings for how WG++ will deal with the EPG data for each channel but will required you to define an update mode for each channel). I usually set this value to incremental (i), which only downloads and writes new/changed data, as follows:

    <update>i</update>

    <channel>

    This is the settings for grabbing data for each channel, and therefore, it’s one of the most important aspects of your config file. At its most basic level, this element indicates a source to grab EPG data from (site), the id of the channel for that source (site_id), and the id of the channel for the XMLTV file (xmltv_id) and the name of the channel (<channel>name</channel>). (Of note, if you’ve customized the tvg-id of a mux in a .m3u playlist, setting the xmltv_id to be the same as the .m3u tvg-id will ensure that once TVH has the EPG data, it will automatically map to that channel. Never change the source_id though, as that is for the scrapper to find.) (For more options, see http://www.webgrabplus.com/documentation/configuration/webgrabconfigxml#config_channel.) Also, as we’ll see later, there will be multiple <channel></channel> rows in this file because we usually want to grab EPG data for more than one channel. For instance:

    <channel site="example.com" side_id="channel-example" xmltv_id="Channel Example">Channel Example</channel>
<channel site="example.com" side_id="channel-example-hd" xmltv_id="Channel Example HD">Channel Example HD</channel>

    Right now, you don’t need to bother with adding and editing the <channel></channel> elements. Just delete the dummy channel that is there just for testing purposes.

    If you’re done editing the other settings, save the file and let’s see how we can find the <channel></channel> elements using the siteini.pack/ folder.

    Updating the siteini.pack folder

    Your .wg++/ folder should have a bin/ subfolder that contains the WG++ executable and a file called SiteIni.Pack.Update.sh. The latter file is a shell script that will check the current version of the .ini files you have on your local machine and compare against the latest version available online. (.ini files stored on the siteini.pack folder are files that instruct the grabber how to parse a TV guide website.) If your version is outdated, it’ll update all files sotred on your .wg++/siteini.pack/ folder. To run it, type the following:

    cd ~/.wg++/bin
bash SiteIni.Pack.Update.sh

    After running that script, your local siteini.pack/ folder should be up-to-date. This means we can use it to find a good source for our channels’ EPG data. Now, before we move onto that, let’s go ahead and automate the usage of the update script. As you might have noticed, the SiteIni.Pack.Update.sh script is an interactive script. That is, if it’s necessary to update the local files, it will ask you to confirm before overwritting any file. Unfortunately, interactive scripts make it hard to automate their usage. Fortunately, we can pipe inputs (e.g., “A” for overwrite all) writing a very simple helper script and then create a cronjob to run it every day at 4AM, as follows:

    # Write a bash script to pipe "All" to SiteIni.Pack.Update.sh
nano UpdateIni.sh

# Add the following, changing /path/to/ with the appropriate path:
#!/bin/bash
/bin/echo "A" | /bin/bash /path/to/.wg++/bin/SiteIni.Pack.Update.sh
exit 0

# Create a new cronjob
crontab -e

# Go to the bottom of the file and add the following
0 4 * * * /bin/bash /path/to/.wg++/bin/UpdateIni.sh

# Save and exit (ctrl+x)

    Great! Now we don’t need to bother with manually running the update script anymore. (However, double check your logs the next day to make sure the update script is running as it should. Wrong paths and permission issues are the usual culprits if you’re running into errors.)

    Selecting the EPG data source

    Parsing siteini.pack

    top

    Alternatives to WG++

    As I mentioned in my previous post, there are many alternatives to WG++. By far, the most convenient ones are EPG data providers but those are (almost always) paid services. Honestly, free alternatives, like WG++ and the XMLTV project, mean that you’re gonna deal with a lot of shit to get the service up and running + maintenance. But if you’re into selfhosting, you might actually enjoy that because it provides you learning opportunities and give you more control over what is going on.

    A free and open-source alternative is the XMLTV project. [You can find their Github repo here: https://github.com/XMLTV/xmltv. There, you’ll also find instructions on how to build it from source, install the required Perl packages, build custom grabbers, etc.] You can run their grabbers independent of any other program (e.g., clone their git, build from source, configure the grabbers, and run them) or use the built-in grabbers from TVH (they’re called internal XMLTV grabbers). I’ve tried this before and maybe I’m just an idiot, but it’s a lot of work and the results are inconsistent because the grabbers are not updated very often (websites with TV guides change over time, which means that old parsers might not work afterwards, leading to broken grabbers). But if you’re feeling adventurous, give it a try.

    top

    TVHeadend EPG configuration

    EPG grabber modules

    TVH allows you to feed it with EPG data via UNIX domain sockets. This option is disabled by default but you can enable it as follows:

    # Configuration > Channel/EPG > EPG Grabber Modules > External:XMLTV > Parameters
# Enabled: Checked
# Path: (Copy this path to a file or take note of it)
# Hit Save

    Piping the guide.xml to TVH

    Via Netcat:

    cat /path/to/guide.xml | netcat -U /path/to/xmltv.sock

    Via curl:

    cat /path/to/guide.xml | curl
